# Proof Evaluation 29

\begin{claim}{1}
Let $A \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ be a nonempty set and suppose that $\alpha := sup(A) \in \mathbb{R}$ exists. If $\varepsilon \in (0, \infty)$ then there exists $a \in A$ such that $\alpha - \varepsilon < a$.
\end{claim}

\begin{proof}
Let $a := \alpha - \dfrac{\varepsilon}{2}$. Then $a < \alpha$ which implies $a \in A$. By construction $\alpha - \varepsilon < a$.
\end{proof}
